meta.status: All layers complete. Inter-layer edges mapped. Integration testing pending.

analytical_modes.first_response: Primary causal direction only. Upward for expression, downward for diagnosis. Feedback edges inactive.
analytical_modes.longitudinal: Feedback edges active. Models development, pattern formation, trait change over time.

inter_layer_edge_types.activates: Drive to State. Sub-types: threat, deprivation, satisfaction, activation, exposure, violation, loss, existential_threat, chronic_violation.
inter_layer_edge_types.sensitises: Trait to State. Sub-types: lowers_threshold, raises_threshold, amplifies, dampens.
inter_layer_edge_types.expresses_as: State to Behaviour. Always trait-mediated. trait_condition field specifies the mediating trait configuration.
inter_layer_edge_types.modulates: Trait to Behaviour. Sub-types: amplifies, suppresses.
inter_layer_edge_types.reinforces: Behaviour to State. Feedback. Longitudinal mode only.
inter_layer_edge_types.shapes: State to Trait. Feedback. Longitudinal mode only. Requires chronic or repeated activation.

1.name: Drives
1.description: Universal, pre-conscious motivational forces. The why behind all behaviour. Context-independent and stable across time.

BEL.name: Belonging
BEL.description: The need to be connected to and accepted by others.

STA.name: Status
STA.description: The need to be regarded as valuable, capable, or superior relative to others.

SAF.name: Safety
SAF.description: The need to avoid threat, harm, or loss across physical and social domains.

AUT.name: Autonomy
AUT.description: The need to be the origin of one's own actions; to not be controlled.

MEA.name: Meaning
MEA.description: The need for experience to cohere into something that matters beyond the immediate moment.

CMP.name: Competence
CMP.description: The need to be effective, to master things, to not fail.

REC.name: Recognition
REC.description: The need to be seen and acknowledged as an individual, distinct from status and belonging.

PLA.name: Play
PLA.description: The need to engage with experience in a non-instrumental, exploratory mode.

NOV.name: Novelty
NOV.description: The need for stimulation, engagement, and new experience.

TRN.name: Transcendence
TRN.description: The need to experience connection to something larger than the self.

CON.name: Contribution
CON.description: The need to benefit others; prosocial motivation distinct from belonging and meaning.

intra_layer.mechanism: Belonging requires acceptance as part of the group; status requires differentiation within or above it.
Social connection is a primary safety mechanism; isolation activates threat response.
Belonging pulls toward conformity; autonomy pulls toward self-determination.
Shared meaning systems are a primary source of both simultaneously.
Complementary within a group; conflicting at the group boundary.
Social play is a primary belonging mechanism.
Novelty introduces unpredictability that can threaten group stability.
Collective transcendence satisfies both simultaneously.
Prosocial behaviour strengthens social bonds.
Higher status generates resources and social protection.
Complementary at high status; conflicting at low status.
Status is externally conferred and relative; meaning is internally constructed.
Competence is the primary legitimate status-acquisition mechanism.
Status is rank-based, recognition is witness-based, but they reinforce each other.
Play is non-instrumental; status is comparative and instrumental.
Transcendence involves self-dissolution; status requires self-assertion.
Public contribution generates status; anonymous contribution conflicts with status-seeking.
Autonomy involves tolerating risk; safety drives risk avoidance.
Coherent meaning systems provide existential safety.
Competence reduces vulnerability and increases predictability.
Play requires sufficient safety; high safety drive suppresses play.
Novelty introduces unpredictability; safety requires predictability.
Transcendence involves boundary dissolution which activates safety threat.
Contribution requires extending resources toward others, creating vulnerability.
Self-authored meaning is a primary and durable meaning source.
Competence enables autonomous action.
Recognition requires others' validation, introducing external dependency.
Play is intrinsically self-directed; autonomy is its enabling condition.
Novelty-seeking is amplified by autonomy; constraint suppresses exploration.
Transcendence involves surrendering self-determination.
Self-directed contribution is autonomy-satisfying; coerced contribution frustrates both.
Mastery and efficacy are primary meaning-generating experiences.
Play can generate meaning but conflicts with meaning's coherence requirement.
Too much novelty disrupts meaning-making coherence.
Transcendent experience is a primary meaning-generating event.
Contribution generates meaning as a feedback product. Direction: CON generates MEA.
Demonstrated competence generates recognition; recognition confirms competence.
Play is a primary competence-development mechanism.
Novelty challenges existing competence and drives development.
Effective contribution requires and develops competence.
Transcendence involves dissolution of individual self-boundary; recognition requires individual distinction.
Contribution is a primary recognition-generating mechanism.
Play is the primary mode through which novelty is explored safely.
Play at high intensity is a reliable transcendence-generating mechanism.
Intense novel experience is a consistent transcendence trigger.

2.name: States
2.description: Transient internal conditions triggered by situational events interacting with drives. Time-limited, affectively charged, and motivationally directional.

ANX.name: Anxiety
ANX.description: SAF threat activation. Pushes toward safety-restoring behaviour.

SHA.name: Shame
SHA.description: BEL + REC simultaneous collapse. Self is defective. Pushes toward hiding or defensive anger.

GUI.name: Guilt
GUI.description: CON norm violation. Other-focused. Motivates reparative behaviour.

LON.name: Loneliness
LON.description: BEL deprivation (chronic absence). Pushes toward proximity-seeking.

ANG.name: Anger
ANG.description: AUT violation primary trigger. Pushes toward boundary-assertion or retaliation.

GRI.name: Grief
GRI.description: BEL loss perceived as permanent. Pushes toward withdrawal then meaning-making.

CUR.name: Curiosity
CUR.description: NOV + CMP co-activation. Pushes toward exploration and engagement.

AWE.name: Awe
AWE.description: TRN activation. Pushes toward stillness, narrative, and prosocial behaviour.

ENV.name: Envy
ENV.description: STA threat via upward social comparison. Ambivalent: can push toward competing or inspiration.

JEA.name: Jealousy
JEA.description: BEL threat via third party (triadic). Pushes toward controlling behaviour or reassurance-seeking.

FLO.name: Flow
FLO.description: CMP + AUT + NOV optimal co-activation. Loss of self-consciousness, intrinsic reward.

BOR.name: Boredom
BOR.description: NOV + PLA + CMP deprivation. Aversive state pushing toward stimulation-seeking.

EXC.name: Excitement
EXC.description: NOV activation + sufficient SAF. Anticipatory, forward-directed, energising.

VUL.name: Vulnerability
VUL.description: SAF exposure without immediate threat. Motivationally ambivalent: disclosure or defensive closure.

RES.name: Resentment
RES.description: AUT violation chronic and unresolved. Calcified anger. Pushes toward passive resistance or covert opposition.

INS.name: Inspiration
INS.description: MEA + CON co-activation. Evocation, transcendence of current limits, approach motivation.

PRI.name: Pride
PRI.description: CMP + STA + REC satisfaction. Self-evaluative, achievement-tied. Sustains status and competence-building behaviour.

DEF.name: Defensiveness
DEF.description: SAF + STA simultaneous threat. Attack on self-concept. Pushes toward deflection, counter-attack, or justification.

DIS.name: Disgust
DIS.description: SAF moral/contamination violation. Rejection/expulsion motivational profile.

MOR.name: Mortality Salience
MOR.description: SAF existential threat. Death awareness activation. Pushes toward meaning reinforcement, legacy behaviour, in-group bonding.

intra_layer.mechanism: Sustained safety threat activates self-protective posture
Self-concept collapse triggers safety threat
Shame converts to anger as self-protection
Norm violation activates fear of social consequence
Reparative motivation converts guilt into forward action
Chronic unresolved envy calcifies into resentment
Upward comparison can activate approach motivation
Unresolved anger becomes chronic resentment
Sustained belonging deprivation activates safety threat
Prolonged loneliness transitions toward grief
Drive deprivation activates exploratory motivation
Anticipatory state opens into exploratory engagement
Exposure activates safety threat
Exposure without acceptance triggers shame
Transcendent experience activates meaning and contribution motivation
Mastery experience generates self-evaluative satisfaction
Achievement satisfaction motivates continued and expanded action
Death awareness is a direct safety threat activation
Mortality salience activates meaning-seeking and legacy motivation
Defensive posture escalates to anger under continued pressure
Belonging threat activates safety response
Threat to bond activates protective anger
Moral violation escalates from rejection to confrontation
Later-stage grief activates meaning-making and contribution
Optimal engagement suppresses threat monitoring
Mutually exclusive activation states
Recent achievement temporarily buffers shame vulnerability
Forward-directed motivation displaces chronic negative state
Self-dissolution of awe temporarily disarms defensive posture
Mutually exclusive activation states
Both activated by SAF exposure; frequently simultaneous
Self-concept exposure produces both simultaneously
Upward comparison often paired with belonging deprivation
TRN + MEA + CON co-activation produces both
Loss of relationship through own action activates both
Achievement and anticipation of further achievement

3.name: Traits
3.description: Stable dispositional tendencies that modulate how states express as behaviours. Individual-variable, durable across time.

CHM.name: Charm
CHM.description: Ability to create positive affect and engagement in others through social interaction.

SIN.name: Sincerity
SIN.description: Stable tendency toward authentic expression over performed or strategic expression.

EMP.name: Empathy
EMP.description: Sensitivity to and resonance with others' emotional states.

DOM.name: Dominance
DOM.description: Tendency to assert influence, control, and direction in social situations.

ASS.name: Assertiveness
ASS.description: Tendency to express needs, positions, and boundaries directly.

AGR.name: Agreeableness
AGR.description: Tendency toward accommodation, harmony-seeking, and conflict avoidance.

EXT.name: Extraversion
EXT.description: Social energy orientation and stimulation preference.

OPN.name: Openness
OPN.description: Receptivity to novelty, new experience, and ideas.

EMS.name: Emotional Stability
EMS.description: Baseline volatility of state activation. Inverse of neuroticism. Governs activation threshold and intensity.

RSL.name: Resilience
RSL.description: Capacity to recover from adverse states. Governs recovery rate distinct from activation threshold.

RSK.name: Risk Tolerance
RSK.description: Comfort with uncertainty, potential loss, and unknown outcomes.

CRT.name: Curiosity (trait)
CRT.description: Stable orientation toward exploration and inquiry. Distinct from curiosity as a transient state.

VLT.name: Vulnerability Tolerance
VLT.description: Capacity to remain in and act from states of exposure without collapsing into defensive behaviour.

HUM.name: Humour
HUM.description: Tendency to engage with experience through levity, play, and comic reframing.

FAI.name: Fairness-orientation
FAI.description: Stable sensitivity to violations of reciprocity and proportionality.

CTL.name: Control-seeking
CTL.description: Stable tendency to manage and constrain the behaviour of others and environmental outcomes.

intra_layer.mechanism: Social fluency amplifies extravert energy expression
Accurate emotional resonance deepens positive orientation
Awareness of others' states increases authentic responsiveness
Hierarchy orientation amplifies direct self-expression
Lower baseline volatility makes recovery easier
Stable activation baseline enables greater comfort with uncertainty
Broad receptivity amplifies exploratory motivation
Receptivity to novelty correlates with comfort with uncertainty
Capacity to remain in exposed states enables authentic expression
Levity is a primary charm mechanism
Self-regulation amplifies sensitivity to norm violations
Harmony-seeking suppresses direct self-expression
Conflict avoidance suppresses hierarchy assertion
Managing external variables is incompatible with self-exposure
Constraint preference suppresses receptivity to novelty
Hierarchy focus reduces sensitivity to others' states
High charm can substitute performed affect for authentic affect

intra_layer.basis: Receptivity to novelty correlates with comic reframing
Strongly empirically correlated; kept separate due to distinct mechanisms

4.name: Behaviours
4.description: Observable interpersonal expressions. The only layer directly visible to others. The diagnostic entry point for analysis.

WIT.name: Withdrawing
WIT.description: Reducing engagement, presence, or responsiveness in social interaction.

MIR.name: Mirroring
MIR.description: Reflecting another person's language, affect, posture, or behaviour back to them.

DMN.name: Dominating
DMN.description: Asserting control over the direction, pace, or outcome of an interaction.

PER.name: Performing
PER.description: Presenting a curated, managed self rather than responding spontaneously.

HLP.name: Helping/Caregiving
HLP.description: Actively providing situational assistance, resources, or support to others.

CMP.name: Competing
CMP.description: Seeking advantage, primacy, or superiority relative to others in a shared context.

COL.name: Collaborating
COL.description: Pursuing shared goals through joint effort and mutual contribution.

REA.name: Seeking Reassurance
REA.description: Soliciting validation, confirmation, or comfort from others.

CFM.name: Conforming
CFM.description: Aligning behaviour, expressed views, or presentation with group norms.

REB.name: Rebelling
REB.description: Opposing, violating, or actively subverting group norms or expectations.

VDS.name: Vulnerability Disclosure
VDS.description: Revealing internal states, uncertainties, or perceived weaknesses to others.

BND.name: Boundary-setting
BND.description: Asserting limits on others' behaviour toward the self.

CHL.name: Challenging
CHL.description: Questioning, opposing, or directly contesting another's position, claim, or behaviour.

SIG.name: Signalling Status
SIG.description: Communicating relative rank, capability, or social value through behaviour.

NUR.name: Nurturing
NUR.description: Supporting the development, growth, or wellbeing of another over time.

DFL.name: Deflecting
DFL.description: Redirecting attention away from the self, a topic, or a feeling.

PLC.name: Placating
PLC.description: Appeasing others to reduce conflict or tension, often at own expense.

STR.name: Storytelling
STR.description: Using narrative self-presentation to construct meaning, connection, or identity.

INT.name: Intimacy-building
INT.description: Progressive mutual disclosure and deepening of connection over time.

CTB.name: Controlling Behaviour
CTB.description: Restricting, managing, or constraining others' options and behaviour.

ATT.name: Attention-seeking
ATT.description: Drawing social focus toward the self.

intra_layer.mechanism: Failed deflection under pressure leads to full withdrawal
Reassurance-seeking escalates if unmet
Targeted challenge escalates to broad control assertion
Appeasement behaviour generalises to norm-alignment
Competitive behaviour escalates to subordination behaviour
Successful disclosure initiates the intimacy sequence
Sustained mirroring creates the safety for disclosure
Attention drive activates self-curation
Authentic exposure incompatible with managed self-presentation
Joint effort orientation suppresses subordination behaviour
Asserting limits incompatible with appeasement
Reduced engagement prevents disclosure sequence
Norm-alignment suppresses targeted opposition

feedback_behaviour_to_state.mechanism: Gap between performed and authentic self widens over time

feedback_behaviour_to_state.notes: Generates resentment in the person being controlled

discard_register.reason: Baseline condition not a distinct state
Derivable from CSC + CMP drive sensitivity

discard_register.destination: Emergent from MIR + SIG + VDS in romantic context

integration_testing_flags: REC (Recognition) - mechanistically distinct but least empirically robust drive node
NOV (Novelty) - weakest irreducibility case in Layer 1
TRN (Transcendence) - universality claim weakest in Layer 1
CON (Contribution) - closest irreducibility call; test whether it decomposes into BEL + MEA in scenarios
STA-TRN conflict edge - logically sound but empirically under-tested
BEL-STA conditional edge - validate within-group vs boundary context distinction
HUM (Humour trait) - provisional; borderline between trait and behaviour pattern
STR (Storytelling behaviour) - provisional; sits close to Performing
Narcissistic tendency - test as drive configuration: high STA + high REC + low EMP
Perfectionism - test as trait combination: high CSC + CMP threat sensitivity
Power/Influence - monitor whether STA node is sufficient or requires separate treatment
